text: Bad customer service, horrible for a 4 diamond hotel. Underneath the trained smiles to pacify you they don't do much to fix anything. Spent A lot of money on a Penthouse loft and the room was horrible, wall paper were peeling off in the bathroom and the carpet was wet. They say someone overflowed the bathtub and flooded the place. At least fix the problem before the next guess. So the apologized and invited me back this year to make up for the problem, great right that is a good move until they check me into an suite that had dog urine on the carpet, and they moved me to a lower floor but took them over a day to move me and did not tell me how long it would take we will call you when its ready, 5 calls and 3 visits to the front desk the room was ready at 3 pm the next day waisted the whole day for these people. Too many incidents to be a 4 Diamonds.... I don't think so

4.5 Stars.

Pretty much loved the Vdara. We were here for 3 nights

I thought the $30 early check in fee was a bit over the top but oh well.

The location is more or less perfect. Right next to Aria tucked behind Cosmo (short 5 min walk), connected by tram to crystals, bellagio and monte carlo, you betcha.

Our room, Executive Corner Suite. Super clean, A\/C broken callled service line, fixed in 20 minutes! Amazing service here. Room was sweet, great view of strip, nice extra 1\/2 bath for our guests, full kitchen. We honestly saved a lot of money stying here as we stocked our full kitchen and ate breakfast and lunch daily pretty much.

Our house attendant was awesome, again just really great service. 

The pool is nice and the Market Cafe was very convenient, great prices there too especially on sparkling.

I'm looking forward to our next visit

I am very torn on how I should review this hotel. So let me break it down.

Pros:
- Beautiful new hotel. Everything is clean and top notch. The décor is very chic and trendy.
- The rooms are all suites, therefore it's like having your own mini apartment. This is nice if you had to stay here for awhile. You have your kitchen, bedroom, bathroom, and living room.
- Beds are extremely comfy. As soon as you hit the pillow you are asleep (or maybe that is from all the late night adventures :-)
- Overall the staff is very friendly.
- The gym is awesome! Tons of cardio and weight machines, as well as free weights and yoga mats.

Cons:
- They did not have any restaurants. They only place you could eat was the Market Café, which is not that impressive. Not to mention it is only open for breakfast and lunch. There is no place (other than room service) that is open for dinner.
- It is far away from everything (except the Aria & Bellagio). You defiantly have to walk a bit to get to the other casinos.
- It does not have a casino
- It's extremely hard to get a taxi. Each time I needed one, I had to wait at least 20 minutes each time. 
- The cleaning service was not good. They left a mess in my room, a mess that I did not originally make.

Guess after re-reading my review, I would give it two stars. When you think of the endless amount of hotels they have in Vegas, this does not compare to half of them.

This place looks a lot better online than it is in reality. Everything was a lot smaller than expected, from the room to the amenities at the hotel (pool, gym, etc.) to the hotel itself. There is not much going on here, so I would avoid this place if you are looking for a fun Vegas experience. They are also nickel and dime you - everything at the hotel is extremely overpriced and they didn't honor the promotion I signed up (fortunately Expedia stood behind it even though the hotel itself wouldn't). On a positive note, you can find a solid, clean room a very good rate and it is very convenient to other hotels worth hanging out at.

One of the best hotels on the strip. It is in a great location (City Center). It is smoke free and there is no casino. Because there is no casino and no smoking, they always have great deals on rooms. The rooms are very nice and have great views of Vegas. If you want to gamble or shop, you can walk out the front door and go across to Aria and Crystals. It also has access to the Belagio.

I have stayed here twice now - once for pleasure and once for business - and was pleased with my experience both times.
The rooms are GORGEOUS. I recently had the opportunity to stay in the Corner Suite, and it exceeded my expectations. The room featured an unparalleled strip view of the Bellagio fountains, a full kitchen with dining table\/stove\/dishwasher, a washer\/dryer, a huge living room, an incredibly comfortable bed, a large soaking tub, and a really nice vanity area.
I will say that if you are here for pleasure, navigating around the strip can be a little tricky due to an odd location and unmarked pedestrian entrances. And reception at the front desk is hit or miss. My last check-in agent was pretty rude when I asked for a late check-out, and essentially told me that nobody at the hotel could help me. Other than that, I really like this hotel and wouldn't hesitate to stay here again.

If I can give a zero star, I would. It's the WORST experience I've ever had in Vegas. I'm writing this review while waiting for someone to come and fix the AC in our room. It's 100 degree in Vegas and our AC isn't working and we've been waiting for an hour by now. The front desk was not being helpful nor apologized. I highly recommend anyone to stay away from this place. Not only the customer service is very poor, it also is a very dead place since there's no casino nor restaurants. Oh, let's not forget, there's no soap in our bathroom either, so we waited for 1 hour for that too. Simply the worst!

A 5 day stay at the Vdara is not cheap.

There is no parking lot to self park, you must park at the Aria or Bellagio. Valet parking for this place should be included, it's $18 a night with resort fees on top of that for 5 days, it's kind of crazy.

The first night we were in our room staff just walked in without knocking (we had a city view corner suite) We requested an extra blanket and pillows, housekeeping just walked right in without knocking or ringing the bell.. About 3 hours later that night we had another incident, house keeping walked into our room because someone had ordered them to clean up our room (we never called housekeeping other than when we requested blankets) my partner was walking around in his boxers and again, housekeeping just decided to walk into our room. The room is quite large so I am not sure how far they had walked in before I heard them talking. As you can imagine I felt uncomfortable knowing that someone may walk into our room at any minute for the remainder of the stay. Head of housekeeping called to apologize but we still felt that it was a privacy violation.

The next night we ordered room service since it was a bit of a hassle to get back to our car and or take the tram, when our food arrived the room service attendant dropped some of soup on the floor, of course she cleaned it up, but again, not what we are paying for.

The parking situation, we had to use a key card to get in and out of the Vdara, at least 3 times our card did not work. When we checked into the hotel the hospitality staff at the front desk did not ask for our parking ticket to include it on the key card so we can get in and out of the parking lot. Thankfully Aria parking lot staff was helpful and advised us how to make our lives easier with the parking situation.

I do not think we will ever be staying at the Vdara again. I have stayed at many hotels \/ suites in Vegas over the part 10 years and this was the first time I was unhappy with our stay.

The rooms were enjoyable overall, it was a nice and quiet place to be away from the hustle and bustle of the casinos but the service should be addressed.

Definitely not staying here again.
Great Hotel ... Great views ... Loved our stay - close to everything not far from the strip.

I was really excited to stay here based about the review but I will not.  I was able to upgrade because of the offer we rec'vd so I thought for sure our room was going to be top notch...not so much.  Our room was so dirty, had not been cleaned in weeks.  Dust everywhere.  The window outside of our room in the hallway had cigarette budgs.  Cleaning service never bothered to wipe that down.  We had a suite so I thought we would have access to kitchen stuff since we did have a kitchen but not the case.  Not a fork, spoon, knive available everything has to be ordered a la carte as well as a coffee maker.  They will offer a Keurig for $25 a day.

I love this hotel. I'm supposed to check out, but I want to move in! 

So much value for what you pay. You basically get a small apartment with an awesome little kitchen. Very tranquil compared to a lot of other places in Vegas, but still very close to everything. (It's right behind The Cosmopolitan.) 

Their room service took pity on me when I had waited 2hrs for a failed GrubHub order to arrive. They had a DELICIOUS veggie burger with TONS of avocado on it to me within like 10 minutes. 

Their bartender was so nice to me as well - she told me to just "make up a drink" when I couldn't pick from the menu. 

A hotel that gives you lots of avocado, the exact cocktail I want and free wifi just gets me - you know? Plus I think they allow dogs! 

Anyways - a great spot if you're looking for a home away from home while in Vegas. I usually only come to Vegas for work, but Vdara has made me want to come back for vacation.

Beautiful hotel, clean ,quiet , comfortable, and non smoking.. rare in Vegas. The water pressure in shower could have been better and the toilet was not in separate room.  A friend mentioned no coffee maker. I did not notice as I do not drink coffee.  A bit of a hike to walk to strip. Service was great. Ate Breakfast at Silks, service and food was great.
Eh. Beds are not comfortable and the pillows are horrible. The hotel is just OK. Nice modern feel with good views but not what you would expect for what you pay.

We ordered the "Studio Parlor Suite" with 1 king and 1 sofa bed, kitchenette with stovetop and microwave, dining room and sitting area, bathroom with bathtub and shower. It was $155.23 a night through hotels.com, not including tax recovery charges + service fees.

POSITIVES:
- Clean shampoo-like smell when you enter the hotel. Simply delightful.
- Modern, clean hotel facilities. High-class all around.
- Easy to navigate.
- TWO 42-inch flat-screen TVs that were back to back. One facing the king bed, one facing the sofa bed. Yes, they work at the same time.
- Free WiFi, no login, seemed pretty fast.
- Gorgeous bathroom with a sliding door that is so quiet, great for sleeping guests.
- Motorized window blinds and shades that you can operate by pressing some wall buttons.
- Stellar window view
- No plastic housekeeping door hangers. Inside the room, you press a button by the side of the door which indicates "Do not disturb" or the other requesting service. On the outside of the room, a circle is lit in different colors by your door accordingly.
- No worrying about being bothered by noisy neighbors. So quiet as you sleep.
- Staff service attitude was pleasant - very polite and professional.
- Mannerly valet service. When you call them to bring the car around, they bring it out pronto. No wait time.

NEGATIVES:
- Parking is costly. $18 for 24-hr valet (I forget the other hourly amounts). Vdara doesn't have its own parking lot so you have to find a spot at the neighboring Aria or Bellagio's parking lots with a 10 minute walking distance they said. $10 for self-parking at the Aria. Might as well valet...
- No pots\/pans\/plates\/utensils in the kitchen. You may request for plates and utensils though.
- No coffee machine in the room.
- The fridge, which was super tiny, didn't seem cold at all. No freezer.
- Sofa bed had no bedding and pillows in the room. You had to request for it. Called them once and they said they'll bring it up. Waited almost at least an hour before calling again and they came promptly and set it up.
- The TVs are glitchy. Turn them on, try to change the options to TV\/Movies\/Music, and in a few seconds, the TV screen turns pitch black as if it were asleep\/hibernating. Turn off, turn on, try the same thing and it goes to sleep. I FINALLY realized that I have to press the remote control buttons that are labeled "Movies," "Shows," and "Music" or whatever they said. The most user-unfriendly TV ever. No instruction manual or anything explaining this.
- Room temperature doesn't seem to cool down fast enough.
- Bathroom vent near the toilet area is weaksauce. No vent switch either.
- Was rudely awoken at 3-4 a.m. by a hotel staff member asking us if we ordered food. NO. Why wasn't the room number confirmed ahead of time?! This is unacceptable.
- Spa was broken on the day we wanted to use it.
- Housekeeping staff knocked on our door at 11 a.m. as we were about to leave and said she'll come back in 15 minutes. When we returned around 3 p.m., she was still there and needed 10 more minutes...so we sat on chairs because the sheets were wet from the spray she used on it.
- The housekeeping lady was charging her cell phone on top of one of our serving plates, not on the counter. Ew? Disgusting.

We complained to the management and got our resort fees waived. Since they were willing to work with their guests and make the customer happy, I am leaving them a positive review. The Vdara has the potential to be an extraordinary hotel.

Nice looking hotel, better than average staff, if you like a quiet place to stay while avoiding large crowds but not too far from the strip then this is the place for you.... would come back if i brought the kids with us... have a convenient city tram from bellagio to aria... however no casino downstairs...

I really like that this hotel doesn't have a casino. Why? Because it's not overly crowded and doesn't smell like cigarettes. The lobby area is smaller than most hotels, but it didn't take away from the modern and clean feel that the hotel exudes.

The check-in was painless and quick. When we got into our room, it was spacious and very clean. The only negative thing I have to say about this hotel is that their bath tubs are really small and uncomfortable. I would've preferred a comfier bathroom. The toilet was placed across from the shower and it seemed cramped. I didn't like the set up.

The plus is that it's connected to other casinos through a bridge walkway and located near the middle of the strip; so it's close to everything. The wifi here is free and the connection is not as bad as other hotels. I would recommend staying here if you want a clean, smoke-free hotel, but if you're looking for a party-like atmosphere then you're better off at another place.

Great hotel to stay in. It's nice being in a hotel that's on the strip but without a casino. It's centrally located, right next to The Cosmopolitan, The Bellagio and Aria. Theres no real dining options in the hotel, but you're close enough to other properties to go grab some food. 

We stayed in a Panoramic Suite that had a great view of the city and it was a lot cheaper than other comparable hotels. 

Wi-Fi is included in resort fee, and is not too slow. Our room included a full fridge, a dishwasher, cooktop and washer and dryer. You don't get any plates or anything which is kind of inconvenient, but I heard that you can get them brought up to you.

Very professional from checking in and checking out with the front desk. My husband and I were celebrating our 1 year wedding anniversary and wanted a hotel that was gorgeous without all the commotion of a casino and drunks walking around everywhere. The lobby bar was exceptional with their small plates and cocktails were soo good (great place to people watch). Our hotel view from the 51st floor was awesome at night as well as during the day overlooking the Bellagio fountain. Housekeeping was fabulous with replenishing our complimentary water and keeping our room tidy. All around great experience!

The stay at the Vdara was fantastic!  We visit Las Vegas several times a year and will never stay anywhere else again.  Summer upgraded us when we checked in from the panoramic suite to the one bedroom penthouse and it was lovely!  The suite looked out over the fountains at the Bellagio - the view was to die for!  There was a full kitchen and washer and dryer in the unit.  There was a large soaking tub and very nice shower.  We absolutely loved the Vdara!!!

I have been staying at the Vdara for the better part of a year on a regular basis, at least once or twice a month. Over the past year I have always been a huge customer advocate for the Vdara and told my friends and business associates that if they are traveling to Vegas your hotel should the their destination of choice.
 
However over the last couple of months, my customer experience has been less than stellar and I will no longer frequent your hotel during my Las Vegas business trips. Here is a summary of my experiences and how they have effected by decision.
 
In speaking with my business counter part, who stays as frequently at Caesars as I do at the Vdara, he is upgraded with each visit to either a higher floor or larger room. In addition he is always thanked for his loyal patronage and told how much they appreciate his continued business. On my most recent stay (March 2 - March 5) when I checked in, I explained to the employee that many of my previous room charges had not credited to my MLife Account. She said she would look them up for me and when she accessed my file she said "Boy, you stay here a lot" and then gave me a card with a phone number to cal for assistance with my issue. No, thank you for your loyalty Mr Harris or I am so sorry for this inconvenience Mr Harris; just I cant help you but here is a card with a number to call. Stellar service.
 
During my previous stay in February I left two iPhone chargers in the room and asked during my current visit if they could be in a lost and found. The front desk employee was very nice and called the department for in that morning, but then found out that it did not open until 11 AM. She said that she would follow up and call me on my mobile phone with an answer. To this date I still have not heard from anyone, so I will assume nothing was turned in or there was no follow up from the employee.
 
I was also quite shocked on Tuesday morning when I went to the Fitness Center to find out it was under construction. A nice employee at the Spa said that I could use the Aria Fitness center at no charge if I showed by room key, but as it was 49 degrees that morning and I was wearing shorts and a T-shirt that was not ideal. When I asked where the Fitness Center was located in the Aria she said that I could ask the Door Man for directions when I arrived. Really?? Should this not have been something that the front desk notified me of when checking in? Should there not have been some map provided to me at check in with this information? Why was I paying a daily resort fee of $30+ a day and not have use of a fitness center? Lovely.
 
To your credit, the Valet team are amazing. When I arrive each time they always say " Welcome Back Mr Harris" even though they have not seen me for two to three weeks. Perhaps this is because I have a bright orange car or because I am a big tipper, but they are the only ones who treated me like a loyal and valuable customer. I would recommend whoever manages that department is promoted to manage the front desk for a better overall customer experience.
 
So now I have a Total Rewards Card and have booked my first room at Caesars next week. I realize that I will be starting over again with a new program, but I am looking for a company to recognize my loyalty and thank me for my patronage. Somehow your hotel seems to have lost that focus and for that, I am truly disappointed.

Amazing experience at this hotel! My bf and I are locals and he had surprised me with tickets to see Britney at Planet Hollywood for my birthday, but had waited last minute to book us a hotel for the night after the show. Around 5:30pm we went on the app MyVegas to see if there were any good deals on rooms for the night. Although Vdara was posted for a little more than he wanted to spend ($79 thru MyVegas), we discovered it was way cheaper than calling to book where the same room was priced at $248. We booked through MyVegas and checked in around 7pm. When we got to the front desk, we casually mentioned that we had plans to go to the Britney show since it was my birthday and our front desk guy, Dylan, immediately said, "Since we are celebrating a special occasion, let me see what I can do for you." Moments later he had upgraded us from their typical room to their 2 Bedroom Hospitality Suite on the 46th floor! The room was incredible! Two huge bedrooms, the master tucked away within its own quarters. 2.5 baths, a living area complete with seating for 6+ and a full sized kitchen with an electric flat-topped stove, oven, dishwasher, fridge & freezer, wine cooler, cabinets, and even a washer and dryer! It was out of this world!! I felt so special, and my boyfriend and I were so pleased with our amazing accomodations. The girl who wrote about the bed being uncomfortabe is nuts - I got the best nights sleep ever in the massive plush king sized bed. I never wanted to leave!! Thank you Dylan & Vdara for making a local feel so special on my birthday and for making it one I will never forget!!!

I had a bad experience with Vdara so be warned; my review is biased.

Pros: 
Beautiful architecture
Non-smoking
Large heated pool\/hot tub

Here's what happened with me. Vdara guarantees that they'll check you in at 3PM latest. I arrive at 2PM and ask if I can check in early but they inform me that my room was still being cleaned and say they'll call me. I lounge by the pool and wait til 3 but still no call. So I go down and ask about my room. Still being cleaned. I wait til 3:45 and that's when I go to the desk for a third time and I finally have them switch me to another room...which is promptly snapped up by another guest so they have to find yet another room for me which they finally do. After all that, I receive no apologies and of course no compensation. Some guarantee.

So I'm fuming when I arrive at my room. I paid $50 extra for a "fountain view" and stupid me thought it meant I could watch Bellagio's fountain show. Well I could....if I pressed my face against the glass and craned my neck, which rewards me with view of 1\/3 of the pool. I plod back down to the check in counter, ask them about the whole fiasco but am told firmly that it is truly the fountain view. I contemplate changing to another room but at that point, I was a broken woman so I just went back upstairs (after flashing my hotel car at the elevator bouncer for the 5th time) and watched a Say Yes to the Dress marathon.

There is complimentary valet parking - the staff varies and some do not look happy even when given money. And when it gets busy, they drive in a way that looks like they're one inch away from a car accident. I tipped $2 every time I wanted my car (normally I would walk but I was with family members that couldn't walk that far or fast) so I think I spent at least $12 on parking alone.

The final "F You" to me by this hotel was the room itself. You think it being new and all, it would be clean and nice. HAHAHAHA NOPE. The sofa was creaky and very worn and dirty looking like it had been around for decades. And there was a huge, dangerous crack in the glass wall of the shower that would cut you if you accidentally brushed against it. 

Overall I just did not have a fun time at Vdara.

Usually stay at Aria but decided to try something new for a coworkers mini bachelorette getaway. 

-First of all, there is no self park and to even FIND the location was a task for us Vdara newbs. We drove around and around in circles after missing the tiny sign 3 times lol. On top of that, a very unhelpful lady on the driveway told us self parking was on las vegas blvd all the while never glancing at us and playing on her phone the whole time. So not knowing that she meant the Aria self parking we drove around again until we self googled and realized there is NO SELF PARKING! Only comped valet!

-The lady at the front desk was nice and upgraded us to a room with a fantastic view of the Bellagio fountains, the LINQ ferris wheel. Housekeeping and room service were all super prompt and friendly when I "thought" I couldn't open the drapes...(I was just too dumb to operate the switch)

-The room itself was pretty spacious with a king bed..(not sure) and a couch which doubles as a bed. While the bathroom has a walk-in shower and a separate cute tub with not so great shampoos\/conditioners.. A mini stove, microwave, and sink comes equipped with the room and I believe pots are available upon request so its nice if you want to stay in and cook yourself a homey dinner -.- 

Overall, the place is clean and pretty awesome so I'd probably stay here again but NEVER again park at Aria and try to walk over because its super tedious!

It gets one star ONLY because the room was pretty nice. 

But the experience with the valet service ruined the entire stay at Vdara. Sure it looks like they hustle to get your car, uses the sir and ma'am, and open the car doors for you as they should. But thats the easy stuff. The challenges of your job come when problems arise and how you deal with it. 

We waited TWO hours for them to find our car. TWO hours!!! That is the most ridiculous thing ive ever heard. An hour of patiently waiting went by before we confronted the manager about the wait only to hear, "It's really busy, your car will turn up soon." ARE YOU FLIPPIN' KIDDING ME!?! What kind of manager are you!?! Our friends who were with us got their cars 45 min ago and thats the answer you gave me? It took them TWO hours of us waiting before saying that "We lost your car." Seriously?... This really cant be that hard guys and it really took you that long before telling us you lost our car?? They were so much more concerned about getting their tips they kept putting us off. They should have had at least one guy keep looking until they found it or came to the conclusion that it was lost and do something about it then. That determination wouldn't have taken 2 hours. We saw the same guy who was suppose to be looking for our car come back and forth with other people's car. Tips.. All he was concerned about. Learn something about customer service. And you might want to send that manager to management training.

TWO hours!! In Vegas!! That could have made me miss my flight or worse my gambling streak!!

Vdara was amazing. I loved the room and the bed was so comfortable. I now want to go out and buy the bed and pillows they have. Staff was very helpful and if you want a place to stay with no smoking it is perfect. Plus you can walk right into the Bellagio and gamble and eat and drink till your hearts content. So if you want to stay in a comfortable great smelling, very clean place, stay at the Vdara.

Three and a half stars for Vdara.

The hotel is beautiful: very modern, sleek design, beautifully decorated inside. And no casino means no lingering cigarette odors.

The room is really nice. King size bed, pull-out sofabed, a kitchenette with a fridge, microwave, even countertop burners (the hotel will provide pots and pans if asked). The bathroom is almost as big as the room itself. It has both a large bathtub and a standing shower.

The pool is small and pretty standard. There are several cabanas that can be reserved ahead of time, but there are plenty of lounge chairs for everyone's use. 

What knocks my rating down for Vdara are small things which I think a high end hotel such as this one should be able to fix easily. No iPod dock and poor lighting in the rest of the room other than the bathroom. The fridge was not cold enough even though it was set to high: we had to keep our drinks cold in an ice bath. The showerhead had absolutely no pressure. And while the queen size bed was extremely comfortable, the pull-out bed was probably the worst pull-out bed I have had the misfortune of sleeping on. No pull-out bed is comfortable, but this was just bad. Saggy in the middle, and the wire springs poked EVERYWHERE. Sleeping on the floor may have been a better option.

The mandatory $20 resort fee covers free wi-fi in the rooms, use of the pool, and complimentary water bottles each day, among other things. Items\/services requested from housekeeping takes a while to get to your room, but it doesn't mean they're ignoring you: it's because with so many guests, they're usually bombarded with requests, so be patient.

Vdara is conveniently connected to the Bellagio via an overheard walkway, and a tram connects Vdara\/Bellagio with Aria and Crystals mall, as well as Monte Carlo hotel.

Despite its shortcomings, I wouldn't hesitate to stay here again.

We stayed over the weekend in the corner suite. It's a mixed results with the net effect being slightly negative:

1. The sofa bed was broken. We found at about 8 PM. It was never fixed. On the plus side, the hotel gave us another room while they are trying to fix the problem. However, the time that it took them to fix the problem (and the lack of initiative from the management) was disappointing. We had to call several times.

2. The new room has broken bed (on the left side). The support was broken.

3. There was a half-eaten open ice cream in the freezer (seriously?)

4. They compensated us one night. So, the bill was rather low (the only reason that this is a 2-star review).

Other than that, the hotel is modern. The view is awesome and it is relatively clean. I will give Vdara a try in the future. Hopefully, I can upgrade this review.

I've stayed at Vdara before, but this is the first time I've actually booked a room there myself.

This hotel is actually pretty good compared to most Vegas hotels. I normally stay at slightly-lower tier hotels like Paris or Flamingo, but for some reason during the weekend of Feb 16-18, rates here were cheaper than those hotels.

Everyone here was friendly- from the valet and bell carrier outside, the woman (Amanda) at the front desk, the baggage carrier inside, to the room service- I had no problems or second-thoughts tipping them.

The room itself was very nice. As their lowest tiered room (the Deluxe Suite), it is very nicely done with a kitchenette, queen-size sofa bed in addition to the king-size bed, and a nicely done bathroom, I was very pleased with everything about this room except one thing.

The only problem I had with the room was the connectivity panel for the TV. My friends and I were trying to play music from our iPods through the speaker system on the TV via USB, but for some reason, the TV wasn't reading the iPod, even after having gone through the instruction on the TV on how to access the connectivity panel. We were also disappointed with the music system in the room. There was an alarm clock with and AUX attachment, but the sound quality was poor. I expected something better when other hotels offer sound systems with built-in iPod docks that sound better.

I normally don't even bother with hotel amenities other than the pool, but this time I used the fitness center. Free for resort guests, their gym is actually pretty nice. The weightlifting area is pretty small with only two benches, but there were hardly any people there in the first place, except for this one guy. He gave me a weird feeling, and he would randomly sing parts of whatever song he was listening to on his headphones. I can't be too sure, but I think he was also giving me a look. Having had the weird feeling, I avoided eye contact altogether. All I could do was look at my friend who instantly knew what I was thinking.

Overall, this hotel is great. The sound system was just something minor, but I had no problem with everything else.

I'm not sure why this place only has 3.5 stars cause I loved staying here! No its not as chaotic as the other hotels but I love that you can actually breath in this hotel since its non-smoking. All rooms have a great view and I love the full kitchen you get in here! This room could easily fit more than four people since our room had a king size bed and a pull out couch. This place is also CLEAN, a very important factor in my stay. No, its not the most convenient place to stay since you have to walk through other hotels in the strip but I think it all depends on what kind of person you are and what kind of noise level you're looking for. Either way for me, thumbs up!

I love you Vdara!  I love you for your aesthetically pleasing interior architecture, clean lines and design.  I love you for the beautiful view of the pool from my room window.  I love your impeccable service and friendly staff.  I love that you don't have a casino downstairs and there is no odor of smoke within the building.  I love your spa, where I enjoyed the best deep tissue massage by JJ.  Most of all, I love your gym, which I couldn't live without.  

I am not a gal who is enthralled by Vegas.  In fact, Vegas, is not generally a destination I would choose to visit, but after my stay at the Vdara, I have been converted.  I love the Vdara and it made my Vegas vacation a getaway I can't wait to repeat.

I am constantly in utter awe and shock at this establishment...

I have a work trip planned and the company booked us a penthouse suite at Vdara last June, the stay is for March of 2017. The suites have always included airport transportation. I just called to book my transportation and was told that last year, since at the time of the booked, this service was not available, they cannot provide it to me. I find it amazing that after spending close to $1400 for 2 nights in their hotel, Vdara cannot so much as offer a ride from the airport. There are so many establishments, with STELLAR service that goes above and beyond. If you can stay anywhere else, do. I can't wait to deal with the RUDE staff upon our arrival and the lack of service, yet again....

My boyfriend booked this hotel for Super Bowl weekend. I was a little hesitant because there wasn't a casino.  I was pleasantly surprised when we arrived. Aria is very close walk to Vdara and you don't even notice that  that there isn't a casino.  The rooms are very nice and bed is super comfy. I probably wouldn't stay here for a girl's weekend, but this was the perfect spot for a couple's weekend. There was a little store on the first floor that had a variety of alcohol and food options. The prices were very reasonable and not the normal Vegas overpriced casino options.

Words cannot even begin to describe my extremely positive stay at Vdara. All the staff I encountered went above and beyond the call of duty - they were friendly, courteous, warm and engaging. I inquired of the possibility of upgrading to a bigger room and was able to spend three of my five nights at the City Corner Suite which was spectacular to say the least.

This being my first (but not the only!) trip to Las Vegas, rest assured I will be coming back and hands down, Vdara will be THE PLACE I'll stay. I can't think of a better hotel that offers non-gaming and non-smoking to its guests.

I've already spread the word to friends and family that if they are looking for a non-gaming\/non-smoking hotel in Vegas, Vdara is the place to be.

Thank you once again for making my experience more than memorable in so very many positive ways.  Keep up the excellent work all of you are doing, and I hope to see you soon when I return.

I booked thought Hotwire. I think I paid too much
It's not on the strip, it is next to aria entrance and behind cosmopolitan. 
Paid a resort fee - what is that for? Wifi? 
It is well connected to all the adjacent hotels with walkway and tram. 
I like that it does not have a casino and you can walk straight up to you room.
Service is great and it has a small kitchen 
If you are in Vegas for work and tired after a long day and just want some takeout. This is great - since you can heat it up. Great lounge\/ bar area 
Id stay here again but it would depend on cost.

A mindblowing hotel for my first trip to vegas.
Pulled infront and was quickly greeted by a valet for hotel parking. Theres a massive metal structure outside that reminded me of a transformer, this blew my mind and made me very excited to see what i had instore. This hotel sits across the the aria, is not directly on the las vegas strip which made it the perfect place to relax away from the hustle and bustle of las vegas. This hotel has no casino but a lovely bar, eatery, spa, gym, and starbucks Inside. The decor is super artsy and modern with alot of wood on the walls making is a little darker with beautiful chandeliers. This place was fancy! The strip was easy to access, and easy to get away from.

My boyfriend did an amazing job in choosing our Vdara suite. It was unvelievable! This was the nicest hotel experience ever. The setup was studio like, a one bedroom design making you feel at home the second you walk in. The room comes with AC like every hotel in las vegas. Let me help you paint a picture. Walking from the front door your welcomed by a beautiful kitchen with a sink, pantry, fridge, cooktop, and a lovely dining area for 4. Take 10 paces from there you walk into a large living room area with a pull out queen size sofa bed, table, 2 lounge chairs, desk, and flatscreen tv hanging on a built in wall divider. Take 8 paces to the left you are now in the bedroom with a large king size bed with the coziest bedding with two bedside tables, his and hers lamps mounted above head and another flat screen mounted on the other side of the room divider. Open the large screen like sliding door with frosted glass next to the closet and you have an extravagent spa-like bathoom with a soaking tub, standing shower room enclosed in glass, toilet and sink with backlit vanity mirrors. Did I mention the amazing panoramic views through their expansive picture windows (amazing at night with all the vegas lighting), they even came with its own mechanical shade system! Allowing you to control the amount of light you wanted to allow into the room. Housekeeping kept the room stocked with towels and toiletries. The staff were all very freindly and helpful. I didn't want to leave this hotel, I wanted to live there.

My boyfriend treated me this amazing experience. I will remember it for the rest of my life. There are so many wonderful things to say about this hotel. I would come back to this hotel in a heartbeat if I could. It was truly a home away from home and I miss it dearly.

Clean and modern love it. Great service as well. A friend of ours had booked a room in advanced, however they gave us the wrong room number twice! After the third time, the receptionist proceeded to give us an upgraded suite with a kitchen, 1.5 bathrooms, a bedroom, and a pull out bed from the couch. The hotel itself was very clean and I felt like a million bucks walking down the hallway. 

Valet parking only, so be prepared to tip when picking up your cars. Close to the Cosmopolitan, and moderately still close to the strip. Wifi was included for our room! Tons of mirrors everywhere, allowing us to get ready without any crowding. Would definitely come back again.

The place is new and clean and provides a cooktop, microwave and small sink apart from the bathroom.  The fridge, if I remember, was filled with drinks, and you were not allowed to put things in there because there was some weight system that indicated whether you took out a drink or not.  So in other words, you cannot use the fridge even to put your leftovers.

Room was spacious and the pool was nice.  Yes, there is a reflection bouncing off of Aria during a big chunk of the afternoon.  I would suggest swimming in the morning to beat the crowds and for a quiet setting.  Plus, the pool gets murkier in the afternoon...if you know what I mean.

You really can't ask for a more convenient location minus the premium pricing.  You're a small walk from Aria, City Center and the Cosmopolitan.  The hotel lobby connects you to a passageway to the Bellagio and to the tram that connects you to the west MGM properties.  We ended up just valeting our car once and walked during our entire stay there.

The market pantry is very convenient.  It's got foods to take back up to your room, frozen foods for that microwave in your room,  offers coffee, pastries and a fulfilling breakfast.  The oatmeal and omelettes were perfect for my wife and me just before checking out.  You can dine in the pantry as an alternative to breakfast buffets.

Hotel staff was friendly and helpful.  We would target Mandalay Bay in our previous visits, but Vdara has a better location so now it's Vdara that's our primary choice.

Two Words...Hidden Fees.  

Think the Vdara is a good deal for the price...Think again.  They have 2 hidden fees that are the highest in the area.  over 40 a night in hotel fees + 25 a night in parking that are not disclosed when you book and will be charged when you arrive and no longer have the opportunity to cancel or find a different hotel.  Be aware, a room may look like a deal at 200 a night but be certain to add another 30% on top of that when making your decision.

We brought up this frustration to the hotel management when we were surprised at check in and were told "too bad" and lied to about how its the same policy for all hotels.  Bad service, misleading practices....look elsewhere.  MGM for shame.

Great non smoking non gaming luxury hotel near all the action of the Strip. We had a fountain view room on 48th floor and it was a lovely studio; bed is ok  but def not as plush and comfortable as you would expect at a hotel of this caliber. Soaking tub is roomy and nice, separate frameless shower is handy.  Toiletries provided smelled great. Roll out bed from couch provided is also useful but very very uncomfortable. Very helpful staff all around. Cafe downstairs is convenient and with quality made to order food with large portions- expensive for a cafe but this is Vegas and you do get what you pay for. Spa is basic with jacuzzi, hot sauna and eucalyptus steam room, but a good get away for only $30 to use or as part of a treatment you purchase. The vanity had Moroccan oil hair products and the usual styling tools and personal hygiene stuff. Very nice staff there as well. I would definitely return!

Recently stayed here at Vdara with my Girlfriend and we abosoutley enjoyed our stay!! We stayed for 3 days 2 nights. The customer service was great from the moment you arrive at the front. A Vdara employee quickly approached us upon arrival and informed us that the valet there was free (we tipped them of course) he showed us where to go to check in and he called the bell desk to handle our bags and take them up to our room. Check in was super easy. The staff there was great and answered any questions we had without any hassle. Once up in the room the bell man arrived about 10 mins later and handled our bags into the room. He was really friendly and gave us a little tour of the room. The room was absolutely incredible (deluxe suite) we had the perfect view of the Bellagio fountains. We requested that view at check in at no extra charge. We loved the fact that it was a smoke free hotel. It felt good to come back to a refreshing smoke free lobby after being at other casinos. "Aaaaah I can breathe now!!" Haha. We are already planning on staying there again in December. We cannot wait to go back. Thank you Vdara for making me do Vegas differently;)

Undoubtly one of the best accommodations I've had in Vegas! We arrived by car and pulled into the queue of the valet service. Immediately were approached by the valet taking our car key and issuing a claim check for pick up later on. The bellboy also arrived a minute later to take our luggage. Walking into the lobby, the whole place smells good, like flowers! There was no waiting by the front desk, therefore we were check in right away, and ascended to our beautiful room in no time! Our spacious room is uncluttered and modernly appointed. There is a small hallway with a kitchenette as you walk in, which is also a nice buffer between the room and the outside world. The big closet comes with a safe. The large bathroom has a deep soaking tub and a cool shower! The Sealy king size bed, might have been the most comfortable bedding and mattress ever, according to my wife, who is a harsh critique! The environment is extremely well insulated and quiet! That's considering that from most hotel rooms in Vegas, you could hear noise from the hallway or adjacent rooms. Not here at Vdara you don't! You are guaranteed a good night sleep! There's a bar, a mini market and a Starbucks downstairs by the lobby, to attend to your basic needs through the day! There is also a short walkway behind the Starbucks that connects to the Bellagio. Or walk out the front door to the Aria! There is also a "secret" passage to the Cosmopolitan: Go out the front door and make a left as if you were going to the Aria. In about 25 yards, the is an elevator and stairs. Go to the ground level, and though the Cosmopolitan garage to their casino!!

As far as Hotels go in Las Vegas it doesn't get much better than this.  My girlfriend comes to LV on a regular basis and she stays here a lot.   This is one of my favorite Hotels.  You need to make sure that you select the right type of hotel for your visit.  We like Vdara for a variety of reasons but here are a few that stand out; 1-most important the rooms are amazing and we always get a room with a view of the Bellagio fountains, 2-no smoking and 3-it is dog friendly.  Sure it's not a Casino Hotel, but with Aria just across the way or the Cosmopolitan it's not that bad.  The bartenders are great and very personable.

Very nice hotel. Awesome view from our room on the 50th floor. Rooms are spacious with a large bathroom that has a separate soaking bathtub. There is no casino which makes it quiet at night and no gross cigarette smell. There is a convenient train that will take you to the Crystals or the Monte Carlo for free. Good location on the strip.  The elevators are fast and will need to pop your ears around the 30th floor. Drinks are cheaper at the little convenience store than at the bar.
Absolutely gorgeous and free upgrade to a room with a view of the Bellagio waters!  Super clean and spacious. Incredibly well priced which made me question why. Would stay here again in a minute!

I stayed at the Vdara from Saturday to Tuesday in June.  I had not been to Las Vegas since the City Center was built, so it was amazing to see all the new buildings that sprouted up.  The Vdara is located behind the City Center and off to the backside of the Bellagio.  The hotel itself is modern.  I stayed in a Deluxe suite (read: cheapest room) but there was still a view of the Bellagio fountains.  It has a kitchenette, living room and king sized bed.  The bedroom is not truly separate, but there is a wall unit that divides the space for some privacy.  The nightstands had a funky design, but I think that caused it to keep sliding open, especially once you put something in there.  The room was clean and the cleaning staff did a good job cleaning it daily.  There is a button by the door to signal if you want privacy or the room clean, no more door tags!  

Getting around the strip does require some walking.  There is a convenient walkway between the Vdara lobby and the Bellagio tower.  You need to factor in time when walking from the hotel to the strip.  There may be other ways to get around, but that was the most convenient (and air conditioned!).  

The pool area is pretty small compared to most other Vegas strip hotels.  Don't pick this hotel if the pool is important to you.  I didn't witness the Death Ray, I went at 9am to avoid it.  The chairs had umbrellas near by, so there was some shade--I can't say whether the Death Ray would penetrate them.  The fitness area was nice, but they didn't have cleaning wipes for the equipment.

Check out was easy.  There is the $20 resort fee each day which gets you use of the facilities or 2 very expensive bottles of water in your mini-fridge.  More water is in the fitness center.

Overall, it was a very good hotel.  If you don't want a casino right there and prefer a more manageable hotel (less people looking around and checking in\/out), this is a good choice.

At this level of hotel and at this price everything needs to be perfect, and it isn't perfect here:
1. No coffee makers in room.  C'mon -- really?
2. Valet's rarely answer the phone when you call down for your car, the majority of the time you get this message stating that they are busy and you just have to come down and give them your ticket in person -- so this effectively wastes about 10 minutes of your time each time you need your car.  This is just poor staffing and operations.
3. Cleaning people inconsistent -- did not give us new soap, did not wash dishes.

The Wynn is imho still the best place in town,

Good location, nice suites, and non-smoking...me likey!  However I do have a few dislikes and complaints...  

1) they don't honor their own deals and specials as advertised on their website!  What's up with that?  We showed them our email confirmation and their response was "oh, it doesn't show in our system"...WTF?  TOTAL SCAMMERS, SO BEWARE!  

2) the showers suck, water pressure is low!  I respect that this hotel is going green but with pressure that low, I end up taking a longer shower, and wasting more water!  So how is that green?  

3) small and plain pool area.

4) $40 per day Resort Fees!  For a small and boring hotel, $40 is too much especially since they don't have much to offer.

5) Getting to this hotel is confusing.  We were driving around in circles because we kept missing the ramp.  So keep an eye out!

Vdara is my go to hotel when I stay in Las Vegas: I've probably stayed there a total of 30 nights over the last year and a half.

Pros:
- Centrally located to just about every other Strip property. The Bellagio is adjacent and easy to get to, and Planet Hollywood\/Caesars\/Paris\/Cosmopolitan are all within a 10 minute walk.
- The cafe downstairs serves decent food, including grab to go options, at reasonable prices.
- You can get from the front door to your room elevator in about 30 seconds, unlike just about every other Strip property where you have to navigate the casino for several minutes. (Vdara has no casino.)
- Uber and Lyft pickup is conveniently in the main valet area, which itself is next the registration desk area. (Some hotels put these all in different places.) UberX to\/from airport was about $12.
- Security checks that you have a key when you go to the elevator, so it's pretty safe.
- Rooms are larger than standard hotel rooms (but don't think suite means much more spacious than a large hotel room).
- View of the Bellagio fountain (for the rooms that face that way) is better than a lot of Bellagio rooms.
- Plenty of outlets near the bed.
- Awesome light thing at the door to signal do not disturb or housekeeping needed. This should exist at every hotel.
- Valets are very quick.
- Sometimes had to wait for an elevator at peak times but usually not much of a wait.
- Business center is near registration and packages were in my hand within an hour of delivery - again unlike other Strip properties where you had to trek through miles of hallways to retrieve it.
- Quiet, business like hotel - not a more typical rowdy Vegas place.

Cons:
- The booking website is confusing about the different kinds of rooms. There must be twenty different combinations of view, suite, and size with undescriptive names, and although I've booked a dozen times I always struggle with figuring out which is what.
- The path to the Strip could be more direct. You can get to the Cosmo very easily but the sidewalk is then blocked off to further down to the Strip. So you have to navigate through the Cosmo, or go a different indirect route via the Bellagio, to get to the Strip. It's frustrating because it's a straight shot down the street but you have to walk in traffic to do it.
- No coffee maker in room.
- The shower head is not adjustable and is set for someone over 6 feet tall. I'm shorter than that so have to sort of press against the wall.
- I'm MLife Platinum and have gotten very inconsistent stuff for that. Sometimes I get the resort fee waived without needing to ask, sometimes I have to ask and get it waived, and sometimes I ask and don't get it. I've stopped asking the front desk what platinums have access to because they never know. Other properties are now giving platinums a letter with this info at check in but I've never gotten it at the Vdara.

Fixing those cons would make the Vdara perfect but I still rate it 4 out of 5 and it's my go to Vegas stay.

UPDATE: upon checking out, and leaving, we noticed our car shaking a bit weird. Please note, we drove 8+ hours with everything fine and left it to valet in tact. Pulled over at a gas station to check the tire once we headed back home. Seen that our back right tire hubcap was completely dented into the rim. One reason why I was disappointed there was no self park.

Also, last night there was water leaking from a light above the sink. They sent someone up quick which was nice. But really, a light above the sink? What if the light was on.

All in all, I liked this hotel. It was a nice change to not have to deal with the cigarette smoke and crazy crowds that other, bigger hotels have.

Positives:
Rooms were nice and modern with a great view.
Bathroom had a huge, soaking tub.
Convenient location, close to many restaurants and shops.
Starbucks inside near the lobby!
They are dog friendly (I later found out) and even have a dog park on the premises.

Negatives:
The pool was just too small and boring.
The market restaurant near the lobby had the worst customer service and wait time ever.

First stay at Vdara this past Vegas trip due to bringing a 5 month old with us. We didn't want her breathing in cigarette smells and the loud crowd noises in the casino. Vdara is one of the hotels without a casino which definitely helped us in choosing this hotel. Booked a two night stay at a regular suite and upon checking in, was upgraded by the nice gentleman working to a corner suite room. What a gorgeous room it was. Though the room lacked a big living room, it had a kitchen, washer\/dryer, fridge, microwave, king sized bed with queen size fold out in the living room. and a nice sized restroom with window views all around. Definitely one of the better hotels in Vegas I've stayed at and I've stayed at most of the hotels on the strip. If you're looking for a quiet upscale hotel that's cigarette free, stay at Vdara! You also don't get hassled parking at valet and the bell hop guys are friendly!

A very nice hotel WITHOUT any busy casino!

Room - modern, spacious, CLEAN, with kitchen (microwave, fridge, sink, stove top, wine opener)
Staff - very friendly
Valet parking only - the service is much quicker than i expect!
Location - this is right behind Cosmopolitan. Perfect if you are going to Marquee for clubbing, it is within walking distance.
Price - very competitive!

Highly recommend!
Vdara is an amazing hotel to stay in. Went a few months ago with a group of friends has the most beautiful view!

Popped out to the desert last weekend for a quick 30-hour turnaround visit with some friends. Nice way to hit Vegas hard and leave before it hits you back...

This was my first visit to Vdara, and I left largely impressed. Very nice, new hotel in a convenient location that enables you to walk to a lot of places. That's good because when you stay here, you will need to walk to a lot of places. 

On the plus side: 

No casino - means you skip long walks from the reception to the elevator towers.

Great rooms - had a regular suite, which rocked...two tvs, mini-kitchen, sitting area, bedroom, big bathroom. My suite had a great view of the Bellagio fountain, which I would recommend requesting versus the view of the pool.

On the minus side:

Very limited food choices on-site. Expect to go off-campus for anything more than snacks or a simple lunch. We did eat one meal at the pool-side cafe, which was good, but it's tough to mess up a breakfast burrito. Good news is you can walk next door to either Cosmopolitan, Bellagio or Aria and be surrounded with great restaurants. Very easy to get to these other locales. 

Small pool. For a hotel of this size, the pool is small. We were still able to find seats at the pool at 10am on a Saturday, which as most of you know is next to impossible at the party hotels. That being said, the reason we were able to find seats is this is NOT a party pool. Good crowd, not too old, not too many kids, but not a party pool.  But the pool is functional and you can get some good sun and chill. 

The "death ray." This is not fantasy. There really is a death ray at the pool. Seriously, for about a 30-minute period sometime between 1pm and 2pm when the sun reflects just right off the glass walls of the hotel, it's like a laser burning you. We saw heat waves off the umbrellas and heard them literally sizzling. However, it only lasts a short while and the pool has rules about the sun umbrellas needing to be up until after 2pm. So don't worry about it and stay under the umbrellas, unless you want to be the next rotisserie chicken...

All in all, I think Vdara is perhaps one of the best values on the strip for location, newness, and the rooms. Fantastic rooms. Just plan your pool parties and meals accordingly and you'll have a great time.

I stayed here for one night after Pricelining a room for $80.  Seemed like a smoking deal, but after taxes and fees from Piceline - it came to $94.  Then the hotel tacks on a resort fee - of course.  All of this is to be expected, just a friendly 'buyer beware.'

Pros: 
- Located close to Aria and Cosmo (shows, food, gambling, etc.)
- Great rooms with kitchenettes (think of Vdara as the Residence Inn of City Center)
-Well decorated

Cons:
-Not the best value in the star range if you don't need the kitchenette.  I'd reccommend 'THE HOTEL' or one of the Towers (Planet Holleywood Towers, Hard Rock Towers, etc.)
-See below...

When I checked in I was given a handicap room without being told it was one (which I didn't appreciate).  My room featured a huge stain in the middle of the carpet and a shower door that allowed water to leak out even when shut completely.  I reported the shower issue, they sent engineering up, but the problem remained.

So when checking out I very calmly (really) showed the manager a video of the water streaming out under the shower door and expressed my interest in making sure no one else had to deal with this.  She was mildly apologetic and offered to waive the daily resort fee.  I negotiated a $50 credit at the cafe and called it a day.

So in my opinion, not the best customer service (at least for escalations or issues).  I am pretty easy and travel a lot.  So every once and awhile I get to deal with issues.  The manager on duty got a C- in my book.  I was so polite, friendly, fact-based, etc. - and got offered a free resort credit.  Kind of disappointed!

Just got back from 2 nights in Las Vegas at the Vdara. For people who are not gamblers or smokers and want a quiet refuge from that, the Vdara is your place.

Check-in\/Check out was quick, organized and easy. Stayed in a deluxe suite, which was large enough for 2 people. There is a small kitchenette that includes a fridge and a stovetop.

Pool area is fairly small, but still nice. The bar\/cabanas were closed for winter. Not a lot in terms of dining at the Vdara. You can get food at the lobby bar. There's also a small market and a Starbucks in the hotel. But for any real dining, you are better off going to the Aria next door.

Vdara is part of the MGM conglomerate, which includes Aria, Bellagio, MGM Grand, etc. So, entertainment and dining across those properties is easily put on the room bill. We had a $50 food and drink credit-- and they wound up comping our food at Julian Serrano next door in the Aria--which came to about $65.

Parking is really easy, should you have a car. Valet is free and quick.

This was my first time in Vegas. I'm not a gambler, or into clubbing, and have a low tolerance for the d-baggery associated with "The Strip". For me, Vdara was close to perfect.

4.5 stars

I've stayed here twice, each stay 4+ days. 

I simply love this hotel. It is non smoking, no casino, not many children, and just fresh, clean, and spacious. Both stays were for edc so the city and vdara were well prepared for the huge number of travelers. 

The rooms are all suites so that increases the square footage for your stay... if you're staying longer than 2-3 days, you'll love the extra space, especially in the room and bathrooms which are huge. Awesome kitchen area with 4 seats and a table to hang out, buy food, heat up left overs etc. We bought food and drinks and chilled after we got home from edc at 7am... so it's just super convenient.

Automatic shades are bomb. Bed is comfy, bathroom is clean, spacious, modern. Staff has always been nice towards me and helpful. The free gym is sufficient and the pool is on the smaller side but this is a boutique'ish hotel, so if you want day parties head to another casino. 

Speaking of casinos... everyone knows Asians have gambling problems so not having a casino downstairs really saved me (and my friends\/family)money my last two times here. My first time in Vegas I loss badly.

Once you walk in, you're greeted by a non smoking lobby that smells BEAUTIFUL. Literally, I love the smell of this place. I went to cosmopolitan and it was horrible... cigarette smoke fighting with the hotels scent and the underground'ish valet area with car fumes.

The cafe is actually pretty good and not that overpriced, you're not completely off the strip, but it's still new vegas. Friendly servers there. Valet is pretty good but I assume they hired extra for edc weekend. 

Overall, I will probably always stay here when I goto Vegas.

Close to the strip without all of the craziness. This is a non-smoking, casino-less hotel. It almost feels like an apartment complex. Overall it was relatively quiet - we went on a weekend and apparently it was high school graduation weekend so there were some 'rowdies', but mainly in the lobby (i.e. noise wasn't really an issue in our room). Room is well appointed, very spacious, and well kept. There is a Starbucks in the lobby of the hotel, a small bar, and a deli. What we loved most about this location is the fact that there is a covered walkway directly into Bellagio, allowing us to avoid walking a good chunk of the strip. Would definitely return.

Lots of fun provided you don't mind the no casino aspect which I love! Super close to city center shopping and upgraded rooms offer gorgeous views of bellagio fountains plus mini kitchenette is great for leftovers or long weekends.

NO CASINO in this hotel. We took the Tram from Aria to check out this place and asked someone who was cleaning the trash cans if it has a Casino and they said Yes but when we got there, NO CASINO.. =( So we went to Bellagio instead.

I stayed at this hotel with two friends. It is a very new hotel, and very nice. But the customer service is horrible. I have never experienced the worst customer service at any hotel then here. We asked for an extra blanket and about 3 hours later we got it. We called the front desk and asked a couple of questions about what to eat around there and were to go for the night and they gave us no references. When we checked out my credit card was double charged. It took them 2 weeks to give me credit back. Horrible, do not recommend this place to anyone.

We stayed at Vdara for three nights starting May 12th and couldn't have had a better experience. We were in a two-bedroom penthouse on the 54th floor and the view was the best I've ever had in Vegas. Our room overlooked the Bellagio fountains, which provided us a great show each night.

The room itself was also excellent. Great beds, big bathroom with tub and shower, great kitchen, etc... Every staff member we encountered was on top of their game and a did a great job of making us feel welcomed and appreciated. We had room service every morning for breakfast and once for dinner, and the quality of the food and presentation was excellent. The French toast, in particular, was awesome.

There is absolutely nothing I can complain about or would have changed about our stay . It's an excellent property and value. Don't hesitate if you're considering booking a room at Vdara!

I'm a true-blue Palazzo girl, but the man had a conference at the Bellagio so we thought we'd switch it up and stay at Vdara for the convenience factor.  

One of the best things about this hotel is that when you walk in, you aren't slapped in the face with the smell of cigarettes.  Why?  Because it's a non-smoking hotel.  It's also a non-gambling hotel which means it's quiet when you walk in.  Ahhhh.  

For me, the goodness mostly ends there.  The pool leaves A LOT to be desired.  The dining options are EXTREMELY limited and the restroom (inside the room itself), couldn't be any closer to the bed if the designers tried.

The room was larger than most standard Vegas rooms (except for The Palazzo, ahem) because it also boasts a small kitchen which can be useful, I guess.  The living room area was small and the couch was very uncomfortable.  Actually, the bedroom and living room are basically just one big room with a TV wall unit separating the two.  

The biggest plus for the room was that the bed was super comfortable.  And like I mentioned earlier, I have to take away points for the location of the restroom.  Forget the fact that it has one of those frosted glass doors so if you go in there in the middle of the night, the bedroom still gets illuminated if you turn on the light in the bathroom.  Dumb design. Oh, the decorators also need a little schooling on blackout shades because what they had in these rooms certainly did not fit the bill.  Sure they made the room darkER, but that's about it.  There was no blackout to be found.

Overall, it was a pretty hotel in a great location with great access to the Bellagio, but I can't say that I would ever choose to stay there in the future.

Viva Las Vegas.

I love this hotel this was my first time staying here and I loved the customer service ! I consider my dogs part of my family and to have a hotel acknowledge them the way I do is awesome ! When I checked in they gave my dog a goodie bag, I've stayed in many hotels and have never received something like that for my dogs and it totally won me over ! When I come to Vegas I pick a different hotel to stay at every time but I have to say I will be repeating this hotel stay , I love it !. The rooms are beautiful just like the view, they are spacious and the beds are very comfortable! Definitely will be back next month with my furbabies for my birthday !! Only thing I would change is the pool hours, I wish they stayed open a little later because we didn't have time to use them before they started closing up.

This hotel is beautiful! Easily the nicest hotel I've stayed in on the strip. All the rooms are suites with a kitchenette, dining room, living room and large bathroom. Though, there are no rooms with 2 beds so if you have more than two people they will be sleeping on the fold out couch in the living room. 

There is no casino and no smoking (thank goodness!) which I think is why this hotel was a little more quiet and relaxing than others. I never heard drunk people in the hallways or slamming doors at all hours. 

If you are planning on relaxing by the pool you can reserve your lounge chair online ahead of time (for a small fee) and if you are with a large group you can all enter the same group name to insure all your chairs are together. Our group of 10 was able to lounge together right by the pool all afternoon. There is no way we would have found that many chairs together, much less poolside. 

The location is great, right across from the Aria and a short walk to the cosmopolitan. 

I loved my stay at the Vdara!

Just came back from a 4 day 3 night stay at the Vdara. It was my first and last stay at this hotel.  I was part of a large group of very well-traveled friends ranging in age from mid 30s on up who came for a combined bachelor\/bachelorette weekend. I mention our ages to establish we were not just some young punks checking in. In total there were about 15 of us. I booked my room directly through the hotel some booked their room through a deal offered on travel zoo\/Jet. I will warn anyone thinking of staying because of an advertised deal on Groupon, Travel Zoo, Living Social etc. Don't do it! This hotel has an obvious attitude toward those guests who book through these discount sites. Several Rooms were booked as well as one what they call a "penthouse suite" for our bride and groom. This room is in no way what anyone would consider a "Penthouse" It is a basic 2 bedroom suite with a very small living room. The only thing I can say was deluxe about this room is it did have a full kitchen and full size refrigerator but who in the world is coming to Vegas to cook?  If you are one of the rare individuals looking to make dinner in Vegas I guess this would be the room for you. But if your are looking for something "Penthouse" to house a group of friends for meet ups, drinks etc. you are S.O.L.  Because I booked with the hotel directly my room was ready at check in time. Because some of our friends booked through travel zoo their rooms were not ready until hours and I mean hours waited past normal check in time. One of the rooms not ready was the so called penthouse suite. The front desk staff and management just threw up their hands saying there was nothing they could do about the room not being ready because it was booked through Travel Zoo\/Jet and basically said it in a condescending manner like how dare you book through a discount site. Ultimately it should never matter how a guest comes to you once they are in your hotel. Because our bride and groom  and some of the wedding party could not get into their rooms to get ready for already made dinner plans we were late to our dinner by an hour and half. Not once did the hotel offer them "any" vacant room to get ready in while the penthouse was being cleaned knowing we had reservations. Not once did they offer to buy the bride and groom a drink while they waited. Not once did they offer any other services at a comp. These are indeed viable options to sometimes unavoidable room delays that has nothing to do with changing the travel zoo room rate which apparently is a never to be broken commandment read by Moses himself. It made the group of us feel like they were indeed actually punishing my friends for booking through a discount site. Finally they get their room. Only to find out the hotel lost the brides luggage. Seriously Vdara? The bride herself had to come down to the luggage room to locate her own bag which was sitting on a chair in their storage room. Again what did she get for the trouble? A great big shrug from the staff.  I could really go on forever at the problem after problem encountered at this hotel and the overall attitude of not giving a flying fruitcake by the hotel management. But I will finish with a summary of the most ridiculous points.

*Master Switch-If you don't hit this switch located in the doorway none of the lights in your room will work. 

*Dusty-The room furnishing are very modern but our room was extremely dusty.

*Mini bar fridge-I would have gladly paid the overpriced mini bar charge for a bottle of water. But I couldn't because it locked me out. It opened once upon arrival and then locked me out the entire rest of our stay for who knows what reason.

* The blackout shade-They have these fancy shades that are open and closed by a switch on the wall. It's not one continuous shade it's in portions so all the places that don't connect let in the bright Las Vegas sunshine starting at dawn. 

* The pantry\/restaurant\/gift shop- This is the only place in the hotel to buy food\/drink or necessities so it's very busy but not staffed appropriately and has one register for all. Therefore you will wait a long very long time.

*Do not bring professional type cameras. A photographer was hired for one hour to take pictures of our group to commemorate the occasion. The hotel shut us down like we were trying to film a porno in the lobby the security came at us extremely rude which was not necessary.

*Do not have anyone leave anything for you at the front desk. We did a burlesque lesson as a group and the instructor dropped off a gift for the bride. A msg was left in her room that she had a package waiting for her downstairs. When she went to retrieve it they had lost it. Then questioned her as if she was lying about someone leaving a msg. After about an hour they finally found her package.

So to sum up my review Vdara don't do it. Literally stay anywhere else. The back seat of your friends car would provide better customer service.

The only things that kept me from giving this a five star were as follow:

*Very confusing to know where to park?  There is no self park unless you want to park at the ARIA which is very far away from the hotel if you are hauling luggage.  They do have valet which we don't mind.  We love valet but I know not everyone does.  To get to Valet is confusing too. Go into the CRystals entrance not the ARIA.  You would have to drive in a circle.  For first timers... its confusing.  The second time not so much.  
  
*The pool is small compare to other pools in Vegas.  It was kind of overcrowded and I think it was because of the size.  More like family oriented instead of party crowd.  

*Our fridge wouldn't cool.  That sucked we complained about that but they didn't really fix it. 

*The bed was too firm.  I was kind of dissapointed in this because the ARIA beds are the best that I ever slept in.  My husband said it was the same but I don't think it was.

*The front desk told us our resort fee was "taken care of."  When I hear that I think they aren't going to charge us for it but to our suprise they did... $25 each night.


Now... things that were GREAT at the VDARA.

*The smell. As soon as you walk in there is such a pleasant smell.  I love it!

*The room.  We paid $75\/night in priceline for a couple of weekday nights.  It was a great suite.  The view was awesome (Belagio side... we could see the fountains).   It was clean, it was modern, two flat screens. Perfect. 

*The service was awesome as soon as we called for something they would be right up and then followed up with a phone call.  Hardly any wait too. 

*The Gym... great.  I loved their elliptical machine and they had clean towels and water ready at the machine.  


I would recommend the VDARA and I will stay there again.

Beautiful!!!! The nicest place I've ever stayed in Vegas. 3 minute walk to the nearest casino and a somewhat indirect 5-10 minute walk to the strip (depending on what kind of shoes you're wearing). 

No casino, which to most would be a selling point, but after the fact I sort of felt like I missed out on the whole "roll out of bed- go down stairs and make bad financial decisions" thing.

Beautiful hotel.  No direct access to the strip.  You have to go through aria and crystal to get to the strip or through bellagio.  Their own tram doesn't even connect to vdara.  When we checked in it took till 4:30 to get out room even though check in is at 3p.  It wasn't clean. Got our room and the curtains were broken and a panel on one of the drawers were ripped off.  Called to get it fixed and got someone 45 min later.  I then was getting out of the shower and realized the toiletries on the sink were already used.  When I complained they sent toilet paper.   The valet doesn't answer the phone during the day but when we went downstairs everyone was just standing around.  Nice hotel really deplorable service.

This is a really nice hotel. AMAZING views of the mountains from our corner suite. Windows wrapped around on three sides of the room and looking out from the 40th floor everyday was awesome! The common areas of the hotel are spotless. The room itself could use a deep cleaning. Not dirty by any means but it's beginning to show signs of wear and tear. I.E.- carpets weren't very clean, not gross but not clean either, toilet paper holder was coming off the wall, and I had to clean out one of the bathroom sink drains because there was a major hair clog. I felt that someone should be walking the rooms on a regular basis with a little bit more of a critical eye. But PLEASE don't let this sway you away from Vdara, it is a GREAT hotel, COMPLETELY SMOKE FREE, AMAZING VIEWS, nice staff, not crazy busy or crawling with people. It is a great place to stay to get away from the madness that can be Vegas and we will DEFINITELY be staying there again in March when we return. 
One thing that did bother me was there were no pots or pans or even silverware in the unit. Not even a  coffee maker. This seemed odd to me considering it has a fully functional kitchen but you had no way of using it. I was informed that IF I wanted a coffee maker there would be an additional $20 per day charge to the room. Even with Starbucks coffee costing $4.75 a cup this wouldn't be feasible for me to do. I personally felt this was a bit of price gouging. I mean why give someone a fully functional kitchen and then charge them for the things they would need to use it? It would be like giving me a bed and then charging me for the linens if I wanted to sleep on sheets. Just saying......

To be honest, my hotel suite itself was very clean, modernly furnished, and was overall a top notch room. However, my experience with the hotel policy & customer service was horrible. I drove from LA this Saturday for a one night stay to Vegas, Vdara. Unfortunately due to the extreme weather, my overheated car broke down in the middle of the freeway. I explained this situation to the front desk and asked if I could cancel my reservation of the 2 suites that I had booked. They noted to me that it was too late for me to cancel and receive a refund (which I had already somewhat figured they were going to say), and that on top of being incapable of receiving a refund, I was going to be charged a duplicate amount of my hotel reservation as a result of a no show. That's ridiculous! I've never heard of a no show being a duplicate fee of the amount I had paid. It's usually at the most $50 or a low percentage from the booking amount. With that said, I decided to tow my car to get it fixed in Vegas instead of LA in order to avoid the no show charge. I arrived to Vdara after paying a unanimous towing fee, and stood first in the mobile check-in line (I had already checked in & received my room numbers through my phone). For a good 10 minutes, nobody bothered to assist me & when I finally did receive assistance, the employee noted me that the mobile check-in was closed. (They left the line opened & didn't block off the section, so I guess they were just expecting me to just automatically know it was closed?..) Anyways, finally received assistance & checked in to my suite. I left my luggages with the bell boy, so the first thing I wanted to do was call the luggage\/bell desk.
